div.p: In this paper, it is assumed that the rates of return on assets can be expressed by possibility distributions rather than probability distributions. We propose two kinds of portfolio selection models based on lower and upper possibilistic means and possibilistic variances, respectively, and introduce the notions of lower and upper possibilistic efficient portfolios. We also present an algorithm which can derive the explicit expression of the possibilistic efficient frontier for the possibilistic mean-variance portfolio selection problem dealing with lower bounds on asset holdings.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Portfolio selection is concerned with the problem of allocating one's wealth among alternative securities such that the investment goal can be achieved. The mean-variance methodology for the problem, proposed originally by Markowitz [20,21], has played an important role in the development of modern portfolio selection theory. The pioneer work of Markowitz combined probability theory with optimization techniques to model the investment behavior under uncertainty. The key principle of the mean-variance model is to use the expected return of a portfolio as the investment return and to use the variance of returns of the portfolio as the investment risk. Most of existing portfolio selection models are based on probability theory. Typical researches about the mean-variance portfolio selection problem include Sharpe [27], Merton [23], Szego [28], Perold [24], Pang [25], Elton and Gruber [7], Vo ¨ro ¨s [32], Best [2,3], Jacobs et al [15], Alexander and Baptista [1]. The fundamental assumption underlying the Markowitz's mean-variance model is that the future states of asset returns can be correctly reflected by assets' historical trading data, that is to say, the means, 0020-0255/$ -see front matter Ó 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.ins.2007.01. 030 variances and covariances in the future are similar to those in the past. However, this assumption can rarely be satisfied in the ever-changing real asset markets.

Uncertainty is one of the basic facets of human cognition. Traditionally, uncertainty is dealt with through the use of tools provided by probability theory. Though probability theory is one of the main techniques used for analyzing uncertainty in finance, the financial market behavior is also affected by several non-probabilistic factors such as vagueness and ambiguity [18]. Decision-makers are commonly provided with information which is characterized by vague linguistic descriptions such as high risk, low profit, high interest rate [29]. In these cases, it is impossible for us to get the precise probability distribution we need. Sometimes, the estimated values for probabilities may be so imprecise as to be practically useless if we still regard them as crisp values [11]. With the introduction of the fuzzy set theory by Zadeh [38], a number of scholars realized that they could employ fuzzy set theory to manage portfolio in another type of uncertain environment called fuzzy environment. For example, Watada [33] and Leo ´n et al [16] discussed portfolio selection by using fuzzy decision theory. Tanaka and Guo [30,31] proposed two kinds of portfolio selection models by utilizing fuzzy probabilities and exponential possibility distributions, respectively. Inuiguchi and Tanino [13] introduced a possibilistic programming approach to the portfolio selection problem under the minimax regret criterion. Lai et al [17], Wang and Zhu [36] and Giove et al [10] constructed interval programming models for portfolio selection. Ida [14] investigated portfolio selection problem with interval and fuzzy coefficients, two kinds of efficient solutions are introduced: possibly efficient solution as an optimistic solution, necessarily efficient solution as a pessimistic solution. Carlsson et al [5] introduced a possibilistic approach for selecting portfolios with the highest utility value under the assumption that the returns of assets are trapezoidal fuzzy numbers. Fang et al [9] proposed a portfolio rebalancing model with transaction costs based on fuzzy decision theory. Wang et al [34] and Zhang and Wang [40] discussed the general weighted possibilistic portfolio selection problems. Moreover, Lacagnina and Pecorella [18] developed a multistage stochastic soft constraints fuzzy program with recourse in order to capture both uncertainty and imprecision as well as to solve a portfolio management problem. Lin et al. [19] proposed a systematic approach by incorporating fuzzy set theory in conjunction with portfolio matrices to assist managers in reaching a better understanding of the overall competitiveness of their business portfolios. Huang [12] provided two portfolio selection models with fuzzy returns by criteria of chance represented by credibility measure. Fei [8] studied the optimal consumption and portfolio choice with ambiguity and anticipation. In this paper, we discuss the portfolio selection problem based on the lower and upper possibilistic means and variances.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we introduce the basic concepts and properties of the lower and upper possibilistic means and variances of fuzzy numbers. In Section 3, we propose the lower and upper possibilistic mean-variance models for portfolio selection when the investment proportions have lower bound constraints. An algorithm is developed in Section 4 to derive the analytic expression for the possibilistic efficient frontiers. In Section 5, we present a numerical example of a portfolio selection problem to illustrate our proposed effective approaches. Finally, some concluding remarks are given in Section 6.

div.head: Possibilistic mean-variance models for portfolio selection
div.p: Suppose that there are n risky assets available for investment. Let r j be the return rate of asset j; j ¼ 1; . . . ; n and let x j be the proportion of wealth invested in this asset. Set x ¼ ðx 1 ; x 2 ; . . . ; x n Þ 0 ; r ¼ ðr 1 ; r 2 ; . . . ; r n Þ 0 , F ¼ ð1; 1; . . . ; 1Þ 0 . In usual mean-variance type models, r j is treated as a random variable. The random return associated with the portfolio x ¼ ðx 1 ; x 2 ; . . . ; x n Þ 0 is thus r ¼ P n i¼1 x i r i ¼ r 0 x. The expected return and variance of r are given by EðrÞ ¼ r 0 x and DðrÞ ¼ x 0 Vx, here r ¼ ð r 1 ; r 2 ; . . . ; r n Þ 0 and V ¼ ðr ij Þ nÂn are the expected return vector and the variance-covariance matrix, respectively. The classical mean-variance model for optimal portfolio selection can be described as follows [22]:
div.formula: min x 0 Vx s:t: r 0 x P l; F 0 x ¼ 1; x P 0:ð1Þ
div.p: In Markowitz's original model, the inequality constraint r 0 x P l was replaced by the equality constraint r 0 x ¼ l. This change enables the model to generate a suitable solution for an underestimated expected return rate l.

To formulate the mean-variance type model, it is necessary to estimate the probability distribution of the portfolio return. At least, we need to know the mean vector and the variance-covariance matrix of the return vector. It is well-known that financial markets are affected by many non-probabilistic factors. In a fuzzy economic environment, the future states about returns and risks of risky assets cannot be predicted accurately. Due to this fact, it should be useful to construct a new portfolio selection model under the assumption that r j ; j ¼ 1; . . . ; n are fuzzy numbers. This kind of model can better describe the uncertain investment environment with vagueness and ambiguity.

As a preparation for establishing the new model, we need to determine the following values. First, Theorem 2.1 tells us that the lower and upper possibilistic mean values of the portfolio's return r are given by

Under this structure, the lower possibilistic mean-variance model for portfolio selection can be formulated as min Var Ã ðrÞ ¼ x 0 Cov Ã x s:t:

Similar to the definition of the usual mean-variance efficient portfolio, we define the lower and upper possibilistic efficient portfolios as follows.

Definition 3.1. A portfolio x * is called the lower possibilistic efficient portfolio if there does not exist any other portfolio x such that x Ã0 Cov Ã x Ã P x 0 Cov Ã x and M 0 Ã x Ã 6 M 0 Ã x, where at least one of the inequalities is strict. The set of all the lower possibilistic efficient portfolios forms the lower possibilistic efficient frontier, while the set of all the upper possibilistic efficient portfolios forms the upper possibilistic efficient frontier. The lower (upper) possibilistic efficient frontier can be traced out by solving the portfolio selection problem (3), ( 4) for all possible values of l.

As quadratic programming problems, there are some similarities in formulation between the Markowitz's mean-variance model and the possibilistic mean-variance models (3) and ( 4). Nevertheless, these two kinds of models describe asset returns in quite different ways. The Markowitz's mean-variance model is based on probability distributions, where uncertainty is identified with randomness. That is, the rate of return on the ith asset, r i , is treated as a random variable. Although probability theory is one of the main tools widely used for analyzing uncertainty in finance, it cannot fully describe uncertainty since there are some other uncertain factors that differ from the random ones found in financial markets [17]. The approach outlined in [41] suggests a much more general framework for treating uncertainty. The center-piece of this framework is the concept of a generalized constraint. In this perspective, the possibilistic constraints are an important class of generalized constraints. The lower and upper possibilistic mean-variance models are based on possibility distributions (fuzzy membership functions) rather than probability distribution. That is, the rate of return on the ith asset, r i , is represented by a fuzzy number and the corresponding membership function r i ðtÞ; t 2 R, whose value is interpreted as the degree of possibility of the statement that ''r i (t) will be the rate of return on the ith asset'' [5]. The detailed statements can be found in [5,[10][11][12][13][16][17][18][19]26,[29][30][31]33,34,36,40].

If short sales are not allowed, i.e., x P 0, it is known from Szego ¨ [28], Vo ¨ro ¨s [32] and Best [2] that the efficient frontier would consist of a series of monotonously increasing arcs of convex parabolas in the return-variance plane. div.p: The lower possibilistic mean-variance model ( 3) is based on the possibility-weighted average of the minimum of the c-cuts on the assets' returns, which is consistent with the investor who makes his portfolio selection pessimistically. On the other hand, the upper possibilistic mean-variance model ( 4) is based on the possibility-weighted average the maximum of the c-cuts on the assets' returns, which is thus consistent with the investor who makes his portfolio selection optimistically. Basing on the algorithm proposed in previous section, the analytic formulas for the lower and upper possibilistic efficient portfolios can be easily determined, which are given in Tables 1 and2, respectively. All efficient portfolios do not contain securities 1,9,10, i.e. x 1 ¼ x 9 ¼ x 10 ¼ 0. div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we have proposed the lower and upper possibilistic mean-variance models for portfolio selection by utilizing the lower and upper possibilistic means and variances of fuzzy numbers. The relevant notions of the lower and upper possibilistic efficient portfolios are also defined. An algorithm is further devised to explicitly derive the lower and upper possibilistic efficient frontiers for the possibilistic mean-variance portfolio selection problem dealing with lower bounds on asset holdings. Our method can be essentially applied to the case when decision variables have both lower and upper bounds. These results not only extend both usual mean-variance models and traditional efficient frontiers, but can be used to help investors to find optimal investment strategy under complex market situations.
